Kerry Back (kerryback@gmail.com) J. Howard Creekmore Professor of Finance and Professor of Economics



Room 318 McNair Hall TTh 12:30 – 2:00 3/12/2024 – 4/18/2024



Each of us will, in the future if not already, use large language models (LLMs) as assistants. The models and interfaces will change over time, but it is worthwhile to learn what is available now and adapt as things evolve. Undoubtedly, everyone has already used ChatGPT and other LLMs for some purposes. What we will explore in this course is using an LLM with python to perform data analysis, specifically financial data analysis. We will use Julius.AI, which combines a proprietary LLM with a python interpreter (which I’ll call LLM + Python).
At the end of the course, I anticipate that everyone may still prefer to use Excel for most things. However, there are some things for which an LLM + Python is better suited, and there are other things for which an LLM + Python may be faster. In any case, it is worthwhile to learn what can be done with this new tool, so we will be better prepared for the future. It is quite possible that everyone will end up using Python in Excel and Microsoft Copilot, rather than Julius.AI, but Python in Excel is not generally available yet, and, in any case, Microsoft Copilot + Python in Excel will also be an LLM + Python (+ spreadsheet).
The format of the course is that we will successively consider different types of analyses. We will perform each analysis live in class using Julius.AI. Then, your assignments will be to have similar conversations with Julius.
We will spend roughly a third of the course on topics that were covered in Applied Finance. This course will differ from Applied Finance in that we will ask an LLM + Python to do the work for us, instead of using Excel and @Risk. In the other 2/3 of the course, we will cover new topics, including machine learning and forecasting.

Kerry Back (kerryback@gmail.com) J. Howard Creekmore Professor of Finance and Professor of Economics



Room 318 McNair Hall TTh 12:30 – 2:00 3/12/2024 – 4/18/2024



This course will teach how to use large language models (LLMs) to perform financial analysis. As of December, 2023, the best performing LLM is ChatGPT4. It requires a Plus subscription to ChatGPT. We will also use certain plugins. Google has just released its Gemini LLM, which may be superior to ChatGPT4, but how it will be accessed is not yet clear.
ChatGPT and other LLMs have the potential to revolutionize financial analysis. There are three categories of activities where we may find ChatGPT or another LLM to be useful:

Something I could easily do myself but ChatGPT may be faster.
Something I could do myself but I will have to look up how to do it and hope I get it right. ChatGPT will almost certainly be faster.
Something I do not know how to do and would not likely be able to figure out even with Googling. ChatGPT may be indispensable.

ChatGPT is most important for the third category above and least important for the first. But, there is always a possibility that ChatGPT may make an error, and the possibility of ChatGPT making an error we do not catch is also greatest for the third category and least for the first. In other words, when we rely on ChatGPT more, the chances of an error increase. The goal is to be able to successfully use ChatGPT for all three categories with only minimal chance of letting an error get through.
It is not advisable to use ChatGPT or any LLM to perform mathematical calculations directly. Instead, we want the LLM to operate an application that is sure to do math correctly. There is currently no direct path from ChatGPT or any other LLM to Excel, though Microsoft is working on it. The best application to use with ChatGPT at this time is python. It is possible that the eventual path from ChatGPT to Excel will also go through python – Microsoft is currently beta testing Python in Excel. In any case, given current technology, we should use python for AI-assisted financial analysis. The answer today to the question “What financial analysis can be done with ChatGPT?” is “anything that can be done with python.”
So, what can be done with python? Literally anything and everything. We can grab online data or read our own data, do any sort of financial analysis, and prepare Word or html reports. We can also output figures as jpegs or pngs and output data tables as Excel files (though only with data – not with embedded formulas). We can even write entire interactive websites with python.
However, there is a substantial learning curve to doing financial analysis with python. This is where ChatGPT comes in. We want ChatGPT to write the python code. We have to learn how to prompt ChatGPT, and we have to learn how to recognize errors. Learning to recognize errors is not as difficult as one might think, because it is much easier to read python than to write python, just as reading foreign languages is easier than writing them.
The format of the course is that we will successively consider different types of financial analyses. For each analysis, we will first look at python code that I have written to get a general understanding of what we can ask ChatGPT to do. We will then ask ChatGPT to write code to perform the same analysis. We will do this live in class, and then your assignments will be to have similar conversations with ChatGPT and to produce a figure or table or report, depending on the particular assignment.

Assigment 1



You plan to put $8,000 in your retirement account next year. You expect this amount to grow by 3% per year for 30 years. You then hope to withdraw $100,000 per year for 30 years. You currently have no savings. You hope to make 8% on your investments and will make depsoits and withdrawals at the end of each year.

Ask Julius to create a table containing the balance at the beginning of each year, the gain on the investment account each year, the deposit or withdrawal each year, and the ending balance each year. Ask Julius to save the table as an excel file.
Ask Julius to plot the account balance by year and save it as a jpeg.
Now tell Julius to simulate 1,000 possible lifetimes by drawing the return each year and in each simulation from a normal distribution with a mean of 8% and a standard deviation of 15%. What is the mean ending balance and what is the median ending balance?
Ask Julius to create a histogram of the simulated ending account balances and to save it as a jpeg.
Create a report describing the exercise and including the table and figures and information learned. You can ask Julius to write the report, but you are responsible for checking it.

Due by midnight, Sunday, March 17. Submit a docx or pdf file to canvas.








Assigment 2



Estimate the WMT cost of equity capital using the following data sources: adjusted closing prices from Yahoo, MKT-RF and RF from the monthly and annual Fama-French factors files from Ken French’s data library, and the 1-month T-bill rate from FRED. Get the 1-month T-bill rate on March 1, 2024. Use the last 120 months for which all variables are present to compute the beta (remember to subtract RF from the WMT return before running the regression). In general, follow our March 19 conversations. Write a brief report of your results. Include a scatter plot with excess WMT returns (return minus risk-free rate) on the y axis and MKT-RF on the x axis. Include the regression line in the scatter plot.
Due by midnight, Sunday, March 24. Submit a docx or pdf file to Canvas.
